content.justification: This is a direct rule from the example preferred provision, outlining the supplier's obligation.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp's acceptance timeline formally begins upon receipt of this written notice.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier is responsible for formally initiating the acceptance process, which directly impacts their payment schedule.
content.source_insight: Example of an acceptance procedure provision reflecting Zebracorp's preferred position.
content.text: The [Supplier] shall notify Zebracorp in writing when the [Supplier] considers that the [Works] or the relevant milestone has been completed in accordance with this [Agreement], and request [Zebracorp] to initiate the acceptance tests.

content.verbatim_text: Within thirty (30) days of receipt of such written notice [Zebracorp] shall, if satisfied that the [Works] or the relevant milestone has been duly completed and the agreed acceptance criteria is met, issue a certificate of acceptance for the milestone in question. Such acceptance can be partial or conditional as indicated in [Zebracorp’] acceptance certificate.
content.plain_text: Within 30 days of receiving the supplier's written notice, if satisfied that the Works or milestone are complete and meet acceptance criteria, Zebracorp must issue a certificate of acceptance. This acceptance can be partial or conditional, as specified by Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This sets a clear timeframe for Zebracorp's response and reaffirms its right to issue partial or conditional acceptance, providing flexibility while maintaining a commitment to timely review.
content.conditions: Zebracorp is satisfied that the Works or relevant milestone has been duly completed and the agreed acceptance criteria are met.
content.justification: This is a direct rule from the example preferred provision, outlining Zebracorp's obligation and its right to specify the type of acceptance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must adhere to the 30-day timeline for review and issuance of acceptance certificates.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can expect a formal response within 30 days, indicating acceptance or rejection.
content.source_insight: Example of an acceptance procedure provision reflecting Zebracorp's preferred position.
content.text: Within thirty (30) days of receipt of such written notice [Zebracorp] shall, if satisfied that the [Works] or the relevant milestone has been duly completed and the agreed acceptance criteria is met, issue a certificate of acceptance for the milestone in question. Such acceptance can be partial or conditional as indicated in [Zebracorp’] acceptance certificate.

content.verbatim_text: In the event that [Zebracorp] is not satisfied that the [Works] and/or the relevant milestone has been completed or if the agreed acceptance criteria or other agreed requirements are not met, [Zebracorp] shall notify [Supplier] thereof within the aforementioned time limit and, at the request of the [Supplier], provide the reasons for refusing the acceptance.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp is not satisfied that the Works or milestone are complete, or if acceptance criteria/requirements are not met, Zebracorp must notify the Supplier within the specified timeframe and, if requested, provide reasons for refusal.
content.expert_insight: This ensures transparency and provides the supplier with actionable feedback, reducing disputes and facilitating remediation. It's a fair and standard contractual practice.
content.conditions: Zebracorp is not satisfied that the Works and/or the relevant milestone has been completed or if the agreed acceptance criteria or other agreed requirements are not met.
content.justification: This is a direct rule from the example preferred provision, outlining Zebracorp's obligation to communicate rejection and reasons.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must be prepared to articulate clear reasons for rejection within the contractual timeframe.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers have a right to receive timely notification of rejection and the reasons behind it.
content.source_insight: Example of an acceptance procedure provision reflecting Zebracorp's preferred position.
content.text: In the event that [Zebracorp] is not satisfied that the [Works] and/or the relevant milestone has been completed or if the agreed acceptance criteria or other agreed requirements are not met, [Zebracorp] shall notify [Supplier] thereof within the aforementioned time limit and, at the request of the [Supplier], provide the reasons for refusing the acceptance.

content.verbatim_text: The [Supplier] shall promptly remedy any failures or deficiencies in meeting the acceptance criteria set out below and/or such other agreed requirements, and also rectify and remedy any and all defects and deficiencies identified by [Zebracorp] and/or [Zebracorp’s] customer during the acceptance tests and inform [Zebracorp] in writing upon completing such remedial action.
content.plain_text: The Supplier must promptly fix any failures or deficiencies against acceptance criteria or other requirements, including all defects identified by Zebracorp or its customer during tests, and then inform Zebracorp in writing once remedial action is complete.
content.expert_insight: This clearly defines the supplier's obligation to remediate defects identified during acceptance testing, including those found by Zebracorp's end customer, and to formally notify Zebracorp upon completion.
content.conditions: Failures, deficiencies, or defects are identified during acceptance tests.
content.justification: This is a direct rule from the example preferred provision, outlining the supplier's obligation for remediation.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can rely on the supplier to promptly address identified issues and provide formal notification of completion.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers are contractually obligated to promptly fix all identified issues and formally report completion.
content.source_insight: Example of an acceptance procedure provision reflecting Zebracorp's preferred position.
content.text: The [Supplier] shall promptly remedy any failures or deficiencies in meeting the acceptance criteria set out below and/or such other agreed requirements, and also rectify and remedy any and all defects and deficiencies identified by [Zebracorp] and/or [Zebracorp’s] customer during the acceptance tests and inform [Zebracorp] in writing upon completing such remedial action.

content.verbatim_text: [Zebracorp] will issue the certificate of acceptance only after having satisfied itself that such deficiencies and defects have been duly remedied and rectified, and the [Works] or the relevant part thereof has been completed and all of the requirements for issuing the certificate of acceptance in this [Agreement] have been met.”
content.plain_text: Zebracorp will only issue an acceptance certificate after confirming that all deficiencies and defects have been remedied, the Works (or relevant part) are complete, and all agreement requirements for acceptance are met.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical protective clause, ensuring Zebracorp is not obligated to accept until all issues are fully resolved and all conditions for acceptance are met. It prevents premature acceptance.
content.conditions: All deficiencies and defects have been duly remedied and rectified; the Works or relevant part thereof has been completed; and all requirements for issuing the certificate of acceptance in the Agreement have been met.
content.justification: This is a direct rule from the example preferred provision, outlining Zebracorp's conditions for issuing acceptance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp is protected from issuing acceptance for incomplete or faulty deliverables.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must ensure all issues are fully resolved and requirements met before expecting an acceptance certificate.
content.source_insight: Example of an acceptance procedure provision reflecting Zebracorp's preferred position.
content.text: [Zebracorp] will issue the certificate of acceptance only after having satisfied itself that such deficiencies and defects have been duly remedied and rectified, and the [Works] or the relevant part thereof has been completed and all of the requirements for issuing the certificate of acceptance in this [Agreement] have been met.”

content.verbatim_text: The acceptance criteria and acceptance procedures should always be aligned with the end customer acceptance provisions in any such subcontracts that are specifically made for a particular end customer project.
content.plain_text: For subcontracts specifically for an end customer project, acceptance criteria and procedures must always align with the end customer's acceptance provisions.
content.expert_insight: This is a paramount 'back-to-back' requirement. Any misalignment here creates significant financial and operational risk for Zebracorp in pass-through projects. It's a non-negotiable best practice.
content.conditions: Subcontracts are specifically made for a particular end customer project.
content.justification: To ensure that Zebracorp's obligations and rights with its subcontractor are consistent with its obligations and rights with its end customer, preventing liability gaps.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must meticulously ensure alignment to avoid being caught between conflicting contractual terms with its suppliers and customers.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers working on specific customer projects must adhere to acceptance terms that mirror the end customer's requirements.
content.text: The acceptance criteria and acceptance procedures should always be aligned with the end customer acceptance provisions in any such subcontracts that are specifically made for a particular end customer project.
